METHOD: CONTROLLED LABORATORY EXPERIMENTS
Description of method:
Obtain samples of performance at a particular time and place.
Validity of causal inferences: random assignment of subjects:
Usually.
Validity of causal inferences: experimental control of independent variables:
Usually.
Samples: size:
May be any size.
Samples: representativeness:
May be representative.
Ecological validity:
Not unlikely, depends on the task and the context to which it is being applied.
Information about individual differences:
Usually de-emphasized.
Strengths:
Ease of administration, scoring, and of statistical analysis make it relatively easy to apply to representative samples of a population;
Relatively high probability of drawing valid causal inferences.
Weaknesses:
Not always possible to generalize results beyond a specific place, time, and task setting;
Discrepancies between real-life behavior and behavior in the laboratory.
Examples:
David Meyer and Roger Schvaneveldt developed a laboratory task in which they briefly presented two strings of letters (either words or nonwords) to subjects, and then they asked the subjects to make a decision about each of the strings of letters, such as deciding whether the letters made a word; when the letters were related in meaning, subjects made a judgment faster than when the letters were unrelated to a predesignated category.

METHOD: PSYCHOBIOLOGICAL RESEARCH
Description of method:
Study animal brains and human brains, using postmortem studies and various psychobiological measures or imaging techniques.
Validity of causal inferences: random assignment of subjects:
Not usually.
